intro: Bupleurum divaricatum var. opacum, commonly known as the opacous bellflower, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescences and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender stems and lanceolate leaves that are hairy on both surfaces. Its flowers are usually pale blue or white, with five petals arranged in a cluster. This variant is distinguished by its thick, waxy leaves that give it a somewhat opacous appearance, contributing to its common name.
